qa_pairs.question: What major ownership changes and mergers shaped Conning's structure from the 1990s to the 2010s, and how did these events influence its current operational framework?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Conning's structure was significantly shaped by its 1995 acquisition by General American Life Insurance Company (GALIC), which merged its asset management business with General American Investment Management Company (GAIMCO) to form Conning Asset Management Company. This integration expanded Conning's capabilities in managing insurance company assets [S29][S30].<cite>[S29][S30]</cite></statement> <statement>In 1997, GALIC took Conning public via an IPO, listing it on NASDAQ as CNNG, which enhanced its financial flexibility and market presence [S31][S33].<cite>[S31][S33]</cite></statement> <statement>During the late 1990s, Conning expanded through acquisitions, including Schroeder Mortgage Associates LP in 1998 and Noddings Investment Group in 1998, strengthening its real estate and convertible bond management expertise [S34][S36].<cite>[S34][S36]</cite></statement> <statement>In 2000, MetLife acquired Conning Corp., taking it private and restructuring its operations, while Swiss Reinsurance Company acquired Conning in 2001 to bolster its third-party asset management business [S41][S45].<cite>[S41][S45]</cite></statement> <statement>The 2004 merger of Conning Corp. and Conning, Inc. into Conning & Company streamlined its corporate structure, rebranding as Conning, Inc., and integrated its research and consulting divisions, such as the acquisition of Conning Research & Consulting, Inc. from Fox-Pitt, Kelton, Inc. [S54][S56].<cite>[S54][S56]</cite></statement> <statement>In 2009, Aquiline Capital Partners acquired Conning from Swiss Re, leading to strategic expansions like the 2010 acquisition of DFA Capital Management, which added risk modeling software and expertise [S58][S59].<cite>[S58][S59]</cite></statement> <statement>The 2011 joint venture with Cathay Financial Holdings established Conning Asia Pacific Limited, extending its geographic reach, while the 2014 acquisition of Brookfield’s Core Fixed Income Insurance Business expanded its investment office in Manhattan [S61][S64].<cite>[S61][S64]</cite></statement> <statement>By 2015, Cathay Financial Holding’s full acquisition of Conning ensured operational continuity, and the 2016 purchase of Octagon Credit Investors diversified its fixed-income offerings, reinforcing its position as a global investment management firm [S66][S69].<cite>[S66][S69]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] Conning (company)


# Conning (company)



**Conning** is a global investment management firm serving the insurance industry. [S2] Conning supports institutional investors, including pension plans, with investment and asset management products, risk modeling software, and industry research. [S3] Founded in 1912, Conning has offices in Boston, Cologne, Hartford, Hong Kong, London, New York and Tokyo. [S4] ## Company history

Conning & Company was founded in Hartford, Connecticut in 1912 by William Smith Conning. [S5] Conning was born in Slingerlands, New York, just outside of Albany on September 16, 1877, and moved to Hartford in 1904 to serve as office manager for investment firm Hornblower & Weeks. [S6] He founded the firm together with William C. [S7] Goeben, a colleague of Conning's at Hornblower & Weeks. [S8] The firm embraced the technology of the day, providing election returns to clients by wire from New York during President Woodrow Wilson’s t narrow, re-election victory in 1916 over Charles Evans Hughes. [S9] In 1920, Conning & Company installed a bond ticker and moved into a newly constructed building on Lewis Street in Hartford. [S10] In January 1923, Conning Realty Company was incorporated for $50,000 by Conning, Goeben, Mitchell and Charles T. [S11] Treadway. [S12] In 1935, a year shy of celebrating its 60th anniversary, the Hartford Stock Exchange closed after failing to comply with the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the firm was no longer registered with the exchange. [S13] Two of the oldest investment firms in Hartford joined forces when Conning & Company merged with Ballard & Company on December 4, 1942, to become Conning & Company and Ballard. [S14] In late 1948, William S. [S15] Conning’s wife, Carolyn Dermott Conning, died. [S16] Four months later, the widowed Conning died at the age of 71, leaving behind the couple’s daughter, Katharine S. [S17] Conning, who died in 1996. [S18] ### Early activities

In 1950, Conning & Company began offering insurance stock research and advice to institutional investors. [S19] After Conning & Company celebrated its 50th anniversary in 1962, the firm continued to emphasize research and education. [S20] In 1968, the firm became a Registered Investment Advisor with the SEC. [S21] During 1970, the firm branched out into consulting and strategic industry research for senior insurance executives. [S22] By 1974, the firm had 13 Partners and 60 employees operating in Hartford with a subsidiary, Fox-Pitt Kelton Inc., headquartered in London. [S23] The subsidiary provided research on U.S. [S24] insurance companies and banks to institutional investors throughout Europe. [S25] ### Mergers and acquisitions (1985–1999)

In the mid- to late-1980s, the firm formed two new groups: a venture capital unit to raise private equity for insurance investments and an asset management group to manage insurance companies’ assets. [S26] In 1995, Conning Corp. [S27] and its subsidiary Conning & Company. [S28] were acquired by General American Life Insurance Company (GALIC). [S29] Conning Corp.’s asset management business was merged with General American Investment Management Company (GAIMCO) to form Conning Asset Management Company (now known as Conning, Inc.). [S30] In 1997, GALIC took Conning Corp. [S31] public and completed an initial public offering of 2.875 million shares in 1997. [S32] The company began trading on NASDAQ as CNNG. [S33] In August 1998, Conning Asset Management acquired Schroeder Mortgage Associates LP, a small real estate investment company in Manhattan. [S34] Four months later, Conning Corp. [S35] and Conning Asset Management acquired Noddings Investment Group, a small convertible bond asset manager and broker-dealer located near Chicago. [S36] Conning Corp. [S37] also acquired the insurance company and high-grade fixed income management business of TCW Group, based in Los Angeles. [S38] In 1999, Forbes ranked Conning Corp. [S39] 82nd on its list of 200 Best Small Companies. [S40] ### Expansion (2000–2003)

Passage 2:
[S41] In 2000, MetLife acquired Conning Corp. [S42] and took it private, paying $12.50 a share in cash. [S43] Later that year, Conning acquired Charter Oak Asset Management of Hartford, and also spun out its MarketStance business in an MBO. [S44] Swiss Reinsurance Company acquired Conning Corp. [S45] in July 2001 to build the third-party asset management business. [S46] As part of these changes, Conning & Company’s broker-dealer business was shut down and the remnants were combined with Fox-Pitt Kelton Inc.’s similar business; also, its insurance industry research and publications business was transferred to Fox-Pitt Kelton management. [S47] In 2002, Swiss Re Asset Management's Americas’ asset liability management unit came under Conning's control with 20 employees relocating to Hartford. [S48] In June, Conning Asset Management Company sold its Mortgage Loan and Real Estate business to Key Corp, and in December, Conning & Company and Conning Asset Management Company sold Noddings to First Albany. [S49] In the first six months of 2003, the company spun out Schroeder Mortgage and Conning Capital Partners in MBOs. [S50] Conning US then took over management of SR Asset Management's European third-party asset management businesses in Dublin and London. [S51] Although Swiss Re continued to own the entities, they were renamed Conning Asset Management (Europe) Limited located in Dublin and Conning Asset Management Limited located in London. [S52] In 2004, Conning Corp. [S53] and Conning, Inc. [S54] merged with and into Conning & Company, leaving two entities: Conning & Company and Conning Asset Management Company which then changed its name to Conning, Inc. [S55] Also in 2004, Conning & Company acquired Conning Research & Consulting, Inc. [S56] a research business from its affiliate Fox-Pitt, Kelton, Inc. [S57] ### New ownership (2009–present)

In October 2009, Aquiline Capital Partners acquired Conning & Company from Swiss Reinsurance Company. [S58] In 2010, Conning launched its High-Dividend Equity Fund strategy and acquired the assets of DFA Capital Management, a market leader in economic, capital markets and risk modeling software. [S59] The deal included some of DFA's management team, staff, and ADVISE and GEMS software suites. [S60] On September 20, 2011, Conning and Cathay Financial Holdings received regulatory approval for their previously announced joint venture to form a new Hong Kong-headquartered asset management company, now known as Conning Asia Pacific Limited. [S61] Later that year, Conning and The Phoenix Companies entered into a multiyear investment agreement under which Conning acquired Goodwin Capital Advisers, Inc. [S62] and took management control of the Phoenix's publicly traded fixed income general accounts insurance assets totaling approximately $8 billion. [S63] In June 2014, Conning completed the acquisition of certain assets of Brookfield Investment Management Inc.’s Core Fixed Income Insurance Business. [S64] The investment team managing these assets joined Conning in its newly formed midtown Manhattan investment office. [S65] On September 18, 2015, Cathay Financial Holding Co., Ltd. [S66] (TWSE: 2882), completed its acquisition of Conning through its subsidiary, Cathay Life Insurance Co, Ltd. [S67] This transaction provided complete continuity for Conning and its clients. [S68] On January 31, 2016, Conning acquired Octagon Credit Investors, LLC ("Octagon"), a U.S.-based investment manager with expertise in collateralized loan obligations (CLOs), bank loans and high yield bonds. [S69] In June 2020, Conning Holdings Limited completed the acquisition of a majority interest in the Danish asset management firm Global Evolution. [S70] In July 2023, Italian insurance group Assicurazioni Generali agreed to acquire Conning as part of a partnership with Taiwan's Cathay Financial Holding unit Cathay Life Insurance. [S71] On April 3, 2024, it was announced that the acquisition had been completed.

qa_pairs.thinking:
Okay, let's tackle this question. The user is asking about the major ownership changes and mergers that shaped Conning's structure from the 1990s to the 2010s and how these influenced its current operational framework.

First, I need to go through the supporting context provided. The passage is divided into sections, so I'll start by scanning each part for relevant information. 

Looking at the "Mergers and acquisitions (1985–1999)" section, there's mention of Conning Corp. and its subsidiary being acquired by General American Life Insurance Company (GALIC) in 1995. Then, in 1997, GALIC took Conning public with an IPO. Also, in 1998 and 1999, there are acquisitions of Schroeder Mortgage Associates and Noddings Investment Group, plus the TCW Group's business. These events probably expanded Conning's asset management capabilities.

Next, the "Expansion (2000–2003)" section mentions MetLife acquiring Conning Corp. in 2000, taking it private. Then Swiss Reinsurance acquired Conning in 2001. There's also the spin-off of MarketStance and the merging of broker-dealer businesses. In 2004, there's a merger of Conning Corp. and Conning, Inc. into Conning & Company, leading to the name change to Conning, Inc. These steps likely restructured the company's divisions and operations.

Moving to the "New ownership (2009–present)" section, Aquiline Capital Partners bought Conning from Swiss Re in 2009. Then in 2010, they acquired DFA Capital Management, which added software and expertise. The 2011 joint venture with Cathay Financial in Hong Kong and the 2014 acquisition of Brookfield's business expanded their geographic and product offerings. The 2015 acquisition by Cathay Financial Holding and the 2016 purchase of Octagon Credit Investors further diversified their services. The 2020 acquisition of Global Evolution and the 2023 completion of the Generali acquisition are recent changes, but the question is up to the 2010s, so maybe focus on up to 2015.

Now, I need to structure these events into major ownership changes and mergers. Each event should be cited with the relevant sentence numbers. Also, the influence on the current operational framework would involve things like expanded services, geographic presence, product diversification, and strategic partnerships.

I should check each event and note the citations. For example, the 1995 acquisition by GALIC is [S29], the 1997 IPO [S31], 1998 and 1999 acquisitions [S34][S36][S38]. Then MetLife's 2000 acquisition [S41], Swiss Re in 2001 [S45], the 2004 merger [S54], 2009 Aquiline [S58], 2010 DFA [S59], 2011 joint venture [S61], 2014 Brookfield [S64], 2015 Cathay acquisition [S66], and 2016 Octagon [S69]. 

The influence would include becoming a larger player through acquisitions, expanding into different markets (like Hong Kong, Europe), enhancing their asset management capabilities, integrating advanced software, and forming strategic alliances. These changes likely made Conning more diversified and globally present, which is part of their current operational framework.

I need to make sure each statement in the answer is properly cited and that the sentences are structured correctly. Also, check if all relevant events are covered and that the citations are accurate. Avoid including events outside the 1990s to 2010s, so the 2020 and 2023 events might be out of scope. But the user said up to the 2010s, so maybe up to 2015 is okay. The 2015 acquisition is within the 2010s.

qa_pairs.question: How did Conning's expansion into international markets, such as the UK and Hong Kong, align with its strategic business objectives, and what specific subsidiaries or offices were established?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Conning's expansion into international markets like the UK and Hong Kong aligned with its strategic business objectives of serving institutional investors and expanding its asset management and research capabilities globally. This was achieved by establishing subsidiaries and offices to provide localized services and deepen market presence.<cite>[S3][S22][S61]</cite></statement> <statement>Specifically, Conning established Fox-Pitt Kelton Inc. in London in 1974, which provided research on U.S. insurance companies and banks to European institutional investors, supporting its focus on industry research and asset management. Later, a joint venture in Hong Kong led to the creation of Conning Asia Pacific Limited in 2011, enhancing its presence in the Asia-Pacific region.<cite>[S22][S23][S61]</cite></statement> <statement>Additionally, Conning maintained offices in London and Hong Kong as part of its global network, as noted in its 1912 founding, which facilitated international client engagement and operational scalability.<cite>[S3]</cite></statement>

[S16] Four months later, the widowed Conning died at the age of 71, leaving behind the couple’s daughter, Katharine S. [S17] Conning, who died in 1996. [S18] ### Early activities

In 1950, Conning & Company began offering insurance stock research and advice to institutional investors. [S19] After Conning & Company celebrated its 50th anniversary in 1962, the firm continued to emphasize research and education. [S20] In 1968, the firm became a Registered Investment Advisor with the SEC. [S21] During 1970, the firm branched out into consulting and strategic industry research for senior insurance executives. [S22] By 1974, the firm had 13 Partners and 60 employees operating in Hartford with a subsidiary, Fox-Pitt Kelton Inc., headquartered in London. [S23] The subsidiary provided research on U.S. [S24] insurance companies and banks to institutional investors throughout Europe. [S25] ### Mergers and acquisitions (1985–1999)

In the mid- to late-1980s, the firm formed two new groups: a venture capital unit to raise private equity for insurance investments and an asset management group to manage insurance companies’ assets. [S26] In 1995, Conning Corp. [S27] and its subsidiary Conning & Company. [S28] were acquired by General American Life Insurance Company (GALIC). [S29] Conning Corp.’s asset management business was merged with General American Investment Management Company (GAIMCO) to form Conning Asset Management Company (now known as Conning, Inc.). [S30] In 1997, GALIC took Conning Corp. [S31] public and completed an initial public offering of 2.875 million shares in 1997. [S32] The company began trading on NASDAQ as CNNG. [S33] In August 1998, Conning Asset Management acquired Schroeder Mortgage Associates LP, a small real estate investment company in Manhattan. [S34] Four months later, Conning Corp. [S35] and Conning Asset Management acquired Noddings Investment Group, a small convertible bond asset manager and broker-dealer located near Chicago. [S36] Conning Corp. [S37] also acquired the insurance company and high-grade fixed income management business of TCW Group, based in Los Angeles. [S38] In 1999, Forbes ranked Conning Corp. [S39] 82nd on its list of 200 Best Small Companies. [S40] ### Expansion (2000–2003)

[S41] In 2000, MetLife acquired Conning Corp. [S42] and took it private, paying $12.50 a share in cash. [S43] Later that year, Conning acquired Charter Oak Asset Management of Hartford, and also spun out its MarketStance business in an MBO. [S44] Swiss Reinsurance Company acquired Conning Corp. [S45] in July 2001 to build the third-party asset management business. [S46] As part of these changes, Conning & Company’s broker-dealer business was shut down and the remnants were combined with Fox-Pitt Kelton Inc.’s similar business; also, its insurance industry research and publications business was transferred to Fox-Pitt Kelton management. [S47] In 2002, Swiss Re Asset Management's Americas’ asset liability management unit came under Conning's control with 20 employees relocating to Hartford. [S48] In June, Conning Asset Management Company sold its Mortgage Loan and Real Estate business to Key Corp, and in December, Conning & Company and Conning Asset Management Company sold Noddings to First Albany. [S49] In the first six months of 2003, the company spun out Schroeder Mortgage and Conning Capital Partners in MBOs. [S50] Conning US then took over management of SR Asset Management's European third-party asset management businesses in Dublin and London. [S51] Although Swiss Re continued to own the entities, they were renamed Conning Asset Management (Europe) Limited located in Dublin and Conning Asset Management Limited located in London. [S52] In 2004, Conning Corp. [S53] and Conning, Inc. [S54] merged with and into Conning & Company, leaving two entities: Conning & Company and Conning Asset Management Company which then changed its name to Conning, Inc. [S55] Also in 2004, Conning & Company acquired Conning Research & Consulting, Inc. [S56] a research business from its affiliate Fox-Pitt, Kelton, Inc. [S57] ### New ownership (2009–present)

In October 2009, Aquiline Capital Partners acquired Conning & Company from Swiss Reinsurance Company. [S58] In 2010, Conning launched its High-Dividend Equity Fund strategy and acquired the assets of DFA Capital Management, a market leader in economic, capital markets and risk modeling software. [S59] The deal included some of DFA's management team, staff, and ADVISE and GEMS software suites. [S60] On September 20, 2011, Conning and Cathay Financial Holdings received regulatory approval for their previously announced joint venture to form a new Hong Kong-headquartered asset management company, now known as Conning Asia Pacific Limited. [S61] Later that year, Conning and The Phoenix Companies entered into a multiyear investment agreement under which Conning acquired Goodwin Capital Advisers, Inc. [S62] and took management control of the Phoenix's publicly traded fixed income general accounts insurance assets totaling approximately $8 billion. [S63] In June 2014, Conning completed the acquisition of certain assets of Brookfield Investment Management Inc.’s Core Fixed Income Insurance Business. [S64] The investment team managing these assets joined Conning in its newly formed midtown Manhattan investment office. [S65] On September 18, 2015, Cathay Financial Holding Co., Ltd. [S66] (TWSE: 2882), completed its acquisition of Conning through its subsidiary, Cathay Life Insurance Co, Ltd. [S67] This transaction provided complete continuity for Conning and its clients. [S68] On January 31, 2016, Conning acquired Octagon Credit Investors, LLC ("Octagon"), a U.S.-based investment manager with expertise in collateralized loan obligations (CLOs), bank loans and high yield bonds. [S69] In June 2020, Conning Holdings Limited completed the acquisition of a majority interest in the Danish asset management firm Global Evolution. [S70] In July 2023, Italian insurance group Assicurazioni Generali agreed to acquire Conning as part of a partnership with Taiwan's Cathay Financial Holding unit Cathay Life Insurance. [S71] On April 3, 2024, it was announced that the acquisition had been completed.

qa_pairs.question: What key acquisitions in the 2000s and 2010s enhanced Conning's capabilities in risk modeling and asset management, and what were the outcomes of these acquisitions?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>In the 2000s, Conning acquired Charter Oak Asset Management of Hartford in 2000, enhancing its asset management capabilities. However, specific details about risk modeling improvements from this acquisition are not explicitly mentioned in the context.<cite>[S43]</cite></statement><statement>In 2010, Conning acquired DFA Capital Management, a leader in economic, capital markets, and risk modeling software, which significantly enhanced its risk modeling capabilities. This acquisition included DFA’s ADVISE and GEMS software suites and key management personnel.<cite>[S59][S60]</cite></statement><statement>In 2011, Conning acquired Goodwin Capital Advisers, Inc., expanding its expertise in fixed income asset management. This allowed Conning to take control of The Phoenix Companies’ $8 billion in publicly traded fixed income general accounts insurance assets.<cite>[S62][S63]</cite></statement><statement>In 2014, Conning acquired Brookfield Investment Management Inc.’s Core Fixed Income Insurance Business, strengthening its core fixed income asset management capabilities. This move added an investment team and a midtown Manhattan office.<cite>[S64][S65]</cite></statement><statement>In 2016, Conning acquired Octagon Credit Investors, LLC, enhancing its expertise in collateralized loan obligations (CLOs), bank loans, and high yield bonds, further diversifying its asset management portfolio.<cite>[S69]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] Conning (company)


# Conning (company)



**Conning** is a global investment management firm serving the insurance industry. [S2] Conning supports institutional investors, including pension plans, with investment and asset management products, risk modeling software, and industry research. [S3] Founded in 1912, Conning has offices in Boston, Cologne, Hartford, Hong Kong, London, New York and Tokyo. [S4] ## Company history

Conning & Company was founded in Hartford, Connecticut in 1912 by William Smith Conning. [S5] Conning was born in Slingerlands, New York, just outside of Albany on September 16, 1877, and moved to Hartford in 1904 to serve as office manager for investment firm Hornblower & Weeks. [S6] He founded the firm together with William C. [S7] Goeben, a colleague of Conning's at Hornblower & Weeks. [S8] The firm embraced the technology of the day, providing election returns to clients by wire from New York during President Woodrow Wilson’s t narrow, re-election victory in 1916 over Charles Evans Hughes. [S9] In 1920, Conning & Company installed a bond ticker and moved into a newly constructed building on Lewis Street in Hartford. [S10] In January 1923, Conning Realty Company was incorporated for $50,000 by Conning, Goeben, Mitchell and Charles T. [S11] Treadway. [S12] In 1935, a year shy of celebrating its 60th anniversary, the Hartford Stock Exchange closed after failing to comply with the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the firm was no longer registered with the exchange. [S13] Two of the oldest investment firms in Hartford joined forces when Conning & Company merged with Ballard & Company on December 4, 1942, to become Conning & Company and Ballard. [S14] In late 1948, William S. [S15] Conning’s wife, Carolyn Dermott Conning, died. [S16] Four months later, the widowed Conning died at the age of 71, leaving behind the couple’s daughter, Katharine S. [S17] Conning, who died in 1996. [S18] ### Early activities

In 1950, Conning & Company began offering insurance stock research and advice to institutional investors. [S19] After Conning & Company celebrated its 50th anniversary in 1962, the firm continued to emphasize research and education. [S20] In 1968, the firm became a Registered Investment Advisor with the SEC. [S21] During 1970, the firm branched out into consulting and strategic industry research for senior insurance executives. [S22] By 1974, the firm had 13 Partners and 60 employees operating in Hartford with a subsidiary, Fox-Pitt Kelton Inc., headquartered in London. [S23] The subsidiary provided research on U.S. [S24] insurance companies and banks to institutional investors throughout Europe. [S25] ### Mergers and acquisitions (1985–1999)

In the mid- to late-1980s, the firm formed two new groups: a venture capital unit to raise private equity for insurance investments and an asset management group to manage insurance companies’ assets. [S26] In 1995, Conning Corp. [S27] and its subsidiary Conning & Company. [S28] were acquired by General American Life Insurance Company (GALIC). [S29] Conning Corp.’s asset management business was merged with General American Investment Management Company (GAIMCO) to form Conning Asset Management Company (now known as Conning, Inc.). [S30] In 1997, GALIC took Conning Corp. [S31] public and completed an initial public offering of 2.875 million shares in 1997. [S32] The company began trading on NASDAQ as CNNG. [S33] In August 1998, Conning Asset Management acquired Schroeder Mortgage Associates LP, a small real estate investment company in Manhattan. [S34] Four months later, Conning Corp. [S35] and Conning Asset Management acquired Noddings Investment Group, a small convertible bond asset manager and broker-dealer located near Chicago. [S36] Conning Corp. [S37] also acquired the insurance company and high-grade fixed income management business of TCW Group, based in Los Angeles. [S38] In 1999, Forbes ranked Conning Corp. [S39] 82nd on its list of 200 Best Small Companies. [S40] ### Expansion (2000–2003)

Passage 2:
[S41] In 2000, MetLife acquired Conning Corp. [S42] and took it private, paying $12.50 a share in cash. [S43] Later that year, Conning acquired Charter Oak Asset Management of Hartford, and also spun out its MarketStance business in an MBO. [S44] Swiss Reinsurance Company acquired Conning Corp. [S45] in July 2001 to build the third-party asset management business. [S46] As part of these changes, Conning & Company’s broker-dealer business was shut down and the remnants were combined with Fox-Pitt Kelton Inc.’s similar business; also, its insurance industry research and publications business was transferred to Fox-Pitt Kelton management. [S47] In 2002, Swiss Re Asset Management's Americas’ asset liability management unit came under Conning's control with 20 employees relocating to Hartford. [S48] In June, Conning Asset Management Company sold its Mortgage Loan and Real Estate business to Key Corp, and in December, Conning & Company and Conning Asset Management Company sold Noddings to First Albany. [S49] In the first six months of 2003, the company spun out Schroeder Mortgage and Conning Capital Partners in MBOs. [S50] Conning US then took over management of SR Asset Management's European third-party asset management businesses in Dublin and London. [S51] Although Swiss Re continued to own the entities, they were renamed Conning Asset Management (Europe) Limited located in Dublin and Conning Asset Management Limited located in London. [S52] In 2004, Conning Corp. [S53] and Conning, Inc. [S54] merged with and into Conning & Company, leaving two entities: Conning & Company and Conning Asset Management Company which then changed its name to Conning, Inc. [S55] Also in 2004, Conning & Company acquired Conning Research & Consulting, Inc. [S56] a research business from its affiliate Fox-Pitt, Kelton, Inc. [S57] ### New ownership (2009–present)

In October 2009, Aquiline Capital Partners acquired Conning & Company from Swiss Reinsurance Company. [S58] In 2010, Conning launched its High-Dividend Equity Fund strategy and acquired the assets of DFA Capital Management, a market leader in economic, capital markets and risk modeling software. [S59] The deal included some of DFA's management team, staff, and ADVISE and GEMS software suites. [S60] On September 20, 2011, Conning and Cathay Financial Holdings received regulatory approval for their previously announced joint venture to form a new Hong Kong-headquartered asset management company, now known as Conning Asia Pacific Limited. [S61] Later that year, Conning and The Phoenix Companies entered into a multiyear investment agreement under which Conning acquired Goodwin Capital Advisers, Inc. [S62] and took management control of the Phoenix's publicly traded fixed income general accounts insurance assets totaling approximately $8 billion. [S63] In June 2014, Conning completed the acquisition of certain assets of Brookfield Investment Management Inc.’s Core Fixed Income Insurance Business. [S64] The investment team managing these assets joined Conning in its newly formed midtown Manhattan investment office. [S65] On September 18, 2015, Cathay Financial Holding Co., Ltd. [S66] (TWSE: 2882), completed its acquisition of Conning through its subsidiary, Cathay Life Insurance Co, Ltd. [S67] This transaction provided complete continuity for Conning and its clients. [S68] On January 31, 2016, Conning acquired Octagon Credit Investors, LLC ("Octagon"), a U.S.-based investment manager with expertise in collateralized loan obligations (CLOs), bank loans and high yield bonds. [S69] In June 2020, Conning Holdings Limited completed the acquisition of a majority interest in the Danish asset management firm Global Evolution. [S70] In July 2023, Italian insurance group Assicurazioni Generali agreed to acquire Conning as part of a partnership with Taiwan's Cathay Financial Holding unit Cathay Life Insurance. [S71] On April 3, 2024, it was announced that the acquisition had been completed.

[S26] In 1995, Conning Corp. [S27] and its subsidiary Conning & Company. [S28] were acquired by General American Life Insurance Company (GALIC). [S29] Conning Corp.’s asset management business was merged with General American Investment Management Company (GAIMCO) to form Conning Asset Management Company (now known as Conning, Inc.). [S30] In 1997, GALIC took Conning Corp. [S31] public and completed an initial public offering of 2.875 million shares in 1997. [S32] The company began trading on NASDAQ as CNNG. [S33] In August 1998, Conning Asset Management acquired Schroeder Mortgage Associates LP, a small real estate investment company in Manhattan. [S34] Four months later, Conning Corp. [S35] and Conning Asset Management acquired Noddings Investment Group, a small convertible bond asset manager and broker-dealer located near Chicago. [S36] Conning Corp. [S37] also acquired the insurance company and high-grade fixed income management business of TCW Group, based in Los Angeles. [S38] In 1999, Forbes ranked Conning Corp. [S39] 82nd on its list of 200 Best Small Companies. [S40] ### Expansion (2000–2003)

[S41] In 2000, MetLife acquired Conning Corp. [S42] and took it private, paying $12.50 a share in cash. [S43] Later that year, Conning acquired Charter Oak Asset Management of Hartford, and also spun out its MarketStance business in an MBO. [S44] Swiss Reinsurance Company acquired Conning Corp. [S45] in July 2001 to build the third-party asset management business. [S46] As part of these changes, Conning & Company’s broker-dealer business was shut down and the remnants were combined with Fox-Pitt Kelton Inc.’s similar business; also, its insurance industry research and publications business was transferred to Fox-Pitt Kelton management. [S47] In 2002, Swiss Re Asset Management's Americas’ asset liability management unit came under Conning's control with 20 employees relocating to Hartford. [S48] In June, Conning Asset Management Company sold its Mortgage Loan and Real Estate business to Key Corp, and in December, Conning & Company and Conning Asset Management Company sold Noddings to First Albany. [S49] In the first six months of 2003, the company spun out Schroeder Mortgage and Conning Capital Partners in MBOs. [S50] Conning US then took over management of SR Asset Management's European third-party asset management businesses in Dublin and London. [S51] Although Swiss Re continued to own the entities, they were renamed Conning Asset Management (Europe) Limited located in Dublin and Conning Asset Management Limited located in London. [S52] In 2004, Conning Corp. [S53] and Conning, Inc. [S54] merged with and into Conning & Company, leaving two entities: Conning & Company and Conning Asset Management Company which then changed its name to Conning, Inc. [S55] Also in 2004, Conning & Company acquired Conning Research & Consulting, Inc. [S56] a research business from its affiliate Fox-Pitt, Kelton, Inc. [S57] ### New ownership (2009–present)

In October 2009, Aquiline Capital Partners acquired Conning & Company from Swiss Reinsurance Company. [S58] In 2010, Conning launched its High-Dividend Equity Fund strategy and acquired the assets of DFA Capital Management, a market leader in economic, capital markets and risk modeling software. [S59] The deal included some of DFA's management team, staff, and ADVISE and GEMS software suites. [S60] On September 20, 2011, Conning and Cathay Financial Holdings received regulatory approval for their previously announced joint venture to form a new Hong Kong-headquartered asset management company, now known as Conning Asia Pacific Limited. [S61] Later that year, Conning and The Phoenix Companies entered into a multiyear investment agreement under which Conning acquired Goodwin Capital Advisers, Inc. [S62] and took management control of the Phoenix's publicly traded fixed income general accounts insurance assets totaling approximately $8 billion. [S63] In June 2014, Conning completed the acquisition of certain assets of Brookfield Investment Management Inc.’s Core Fixed Income Insurance Business. [S64] The investment team managing these assets joined Conning in its newly formed midtown Manhattan investment office. [S65] On September 18, 2015, Cathay Financial Holding Co., Ltd. [S66] (TWSE: 2882), completed its acquisition of Conning through its subsidiary, Cathay Life Insurance Co, Ltd. [S67] This transaction provided complete continuity for Conning and its clients. [S68] On January 31, 2016, Conning acquired Octagon Credit Investors, LLC ("Octagon"), a U.S.-based investment manager with expertise in collateralized loan obligations (CLOs), bank loans and high yield bonds. [S69] In June 2020, Conning Holdings Limited completed the acquisition of a majority interest in the Danish asset management firm Global Evolution. [S70] In July 2023, Italian insurance group Assicurazioni Generali agreed to acquire Conning as part of a partnership with Taiwan's Cathay Financial Holding unit Cathay Life Insurance. [S71] On April 3, 2024, it was announced that the acquisition had been completed.
